Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.path

Class Path

java.lang.Object
nl.naturalis.common.path.Path
All Implemented Interfaces:
Comparable<Path>, Iterable<String>, Emptyable, Sizeable
public final class Path
extends Object
implements Comparable<Path>, Iterable<String>, Sizeable, Emptyable
Specifies a path to a value within an object. Path segments are spearated by '.' (dot). For example: employee.address.street. Array indices are specified as separate path segments. For example: employees.3.address.street. Non-numeric segments can be either field names or map keys. Therefore the Path class does not impose any constraints on what constitutes a valid path segment, since a map key can be anything (including null or an empty string).

Escaping

If a path segment contains the segment separator, it must be escaped using the circumflex character ('^'). (Using the backslash character as an escape character would have made it needlessly cumbersome to write path strings in Java code.) The escape character itself must not be escaped. You can let the escape method do the escaping for you. Do not escape path segments when passing them individually, in a String array, to the constructor. Only escape them when passing a complete path string. So "some.awk^.ward.path^string" could also be passed in as: new String[] {"some", "awk.ward", "path^string"}.

In case you need to reference the null key of a Map, use "^0". So "lookups.^0.name" references the name field of an object stored under key null in the lookups map. And you could also pass this in as: new String[] {"lookups", null, "name"}.

Author:
Ayco Holleman

    • escape

      public static String escape​(String segment)
      Applies escaping to a path segment. Can be used to construct complete path strings. Do not use when passing individual path segments as a String array to the constructor.
      Parameters:
      segment - The path segment to escape
      Returns:
      The escaped version of the segment

    • isNullSegment

      public boolean isNullSegment()
      Returns true if this Path consists of a single segment and that segment is null (meaning that this path can only possibly be valid for map objects that allow null keys). Otherwise returns false.
      Returns:

    • segment

      public String segment​(int index)
      Returns the path segment at the specified index. Specify a negative index to count back from the last segment of the Path (-1 returns the last path segment).
      Parameters:
      index -
      Returns:

    • subpath

      public Path subpath​(int from)

      Parameters:
      from -
      Returns:

    • subpath

      public Path subpath​(int from, int len)
      Returns a new Path consisting of len segments starting with segment from. The 1st argument may be negative to indicate a left-offset from the last segment.
      Parameters:
      from -
      Returns:

    • parent

      public Path parent()
      Return the parent of this Path. If this Path is empty, this method returns null. If it consists of a single segment, and empty Path is returned.
      Returns:
      The parent of this Path

      Returns:
      A new Path without any array indices
